flares.note: This flare originated from beyond the western limb, likely associated with former Active Region 14307 which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2025-12-19.

cmes.note: Loop CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. Not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. Associated with a major prominence eruption taking place near 2025-12-15T00:00Z as seen best in GOES SUVI 304, with one footpoint behind the western limb and another near S35W75. Bright post eruptive activity is visible near the centerpoint following the filament liftoff in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit among SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 as well as visible source.
Very preliminary measurement with only estimation of the source longitude using available EUV imagery and three SOHO frames.

cmes.note: CME first visible to the SSW in GOES CCOR-1 only starting around 2025-12-15T12:45Z. The CME is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 and is only faintly visible in SOHO LASCO C2. There is no identifiable source for this CME on the Earth-facing disk, and the front is only visible in running difference imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. This event is not observed by STEREO A COR2 imagery in real time due to a data gap. The source may be related to a small eruption near the southeast limb (centered near ~S20E75) starting around 2025-12-15T23:50Z seen in GOES SUVI 195/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery a triangulated measurement was not available. The measured parameters may vary as a result.

cmes.note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. The start of the CME is not clearly visible in SOHO LASCO C2. The potential source is an eruption seen near the southwest limb seen after a data gap in STEREO A EUV 195 imagery from 2025-12-15T20:35Z to 2025-12-16T01:55Z best characterized as post-eruptive arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Narrow, jet-like CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not clearly visible in GOES CCOR-1 or STEREO A COR2. The source may be a small eruption seen in GOES SUVI 304 around N05E60 starting around 2025-12-16T06:49Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location. The CME is visible in limited SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME faintly visible to the SW in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time due to a data gap. The source may be beyond the west limb as seen from STEREO A EUV imagery, and no clear source eruption is found.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME faintly visible to the south in STEREO A COR2 and to the southwest in GOES CCOR-1. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in real time due to a data gap. The source is likely an eruption from AR 14307 (approximately S15W55) seen as a gradual dimming starting around 2025-12-16T14:40Z in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location.

cmes.note: Faint less than 10 degree half-width CME observed to the W only in GOES CCOR-1, due to a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source may be field line movement on/just beyond the W limb as early as 2025-12-16T22:24Z in GOES SUVI 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with GOES CCOR-1 only, due to the unknown source longitude and being the only coronagraph observing this faint front due to a SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 data gap. The front has a less than 10 degree half-width.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north in GOES CCOR-1 and to the northwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is not seen in real-time by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a planned data gap between downlink periods from 2025-12-16T12:00Z to 2025-12-17T10:36Z. The source is a large far-sided filament eruption observed over the northern limb in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 imagery which begins to lift off around 2025-12-17T02:00Z. This eruption is observed as a far-sided eruption visible over the northwestern limb in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, and to the north in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is seen following a data gap in real-time by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 starting at 2025-12-17T10:36Z. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2025-12-17T06:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north in GOES CCOR-1 and to the northwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is not seen in real-time by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a planned data gap between downlink periods from 2025-12-17T11:48Z to 16:00Z. The source for this event is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraph imagery.

cmes.note: Wide CME seen to the northeast in GOES CCOR-1 and to the northwest in STEREO A COR2 for one frame. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time due to a data gap. Likely associated with far-sided eruptive activity relative to the Earth-Sun line; it is not associated with any eruptive signatures on the Earth facing disk as seen in available SDO AIA and GOES SUVI EUV imagery. The eruptive signature was also not seen in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using one available frame of STEREO A COR2A imagery where the CME appears more narrow than in GOES CCOR-1; the CME width may be slightly wider in reality.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the SE only in SOHO LASCO C2, and even more faint in LASCO C3; not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-12-17T20:38Z, nor in GOES CCOR-1 likely due to faintness. The source may be weak/slow field line movement observed over the SE limb starting around 2025-12-17T18:15Z in SDO AIA 171, which appears to be far-sided in origin.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only plane-of-sky due to the uncertain, likely far-sided, source with no STEREO A COR2 to triangulate with. CME front fades after a few C2 frames, and is near unresolvable in later C3 frames.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and to the NW in STEREO A COR2. In SOHO and GOES coronagraphs, the CME appears as two distinct pieces with an appreciable gap between, yet launch and travel together as one signature, observed in STEREO A COR2 as a much less wide front. The source may be a prominence eruption over the NE limb, observed slowly erupting in SDO AIA 171/304 spanning around 2025-12-17T23:00Z to around 2025-12-17T07:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The CME appears as two distinct pieces to the N and NE with an appreciable gap between, yet likely launch and travel together as one signature from the source prominence, so this anaylsis encompasses the entire eruption as one leading edge feature.

cmes.note: Bright, slow CME observed to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, preceeding CME 2025-12-18T11:00Z as the two overlap. The source is observed far-sided over the SW limb in SDO AIA 171/193 as several concurrent slow, wide field line loops rising and breaking, starting as early as around 2025-12-17T23:00Z and lasting several hours as late as around 2025-12-18T07:00Z. Also observed in STEREO A EUVI 195 as field line movement and some brightening of loops just inside the SW limb as viewed from STEREO A starting around 2025-12-18T01:55Z, following a data gap beginning at 2025-12-18T19:35Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 of the outermost bright leading edge.

cmes.note: Bright, slow CME observed to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, following CME 2025-12-18T03:36Z as the two overlap. The source is likely continued outflow following observed far-sided slow, wide field line loops rising and breaking over the SW limb in SDO AIA 171/193, starting as early as around 2025-12-17T23:00Z and lasting several hours as late as around 2025-12-18T07:00Z. This CME front is likely comprised of several initial CME fronts that appear to collide and travel together as evidenced best in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, using mostly later frames due to the initial CME evolution being quite distorted in early frames and in LASCO C2, appearing much better developed further into the field-of-view.

cmes.note: Faint outflowing CME to the NE observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. No direct source is observed for this CME, but could be far-sided outflow based on previous far-sided NE-directed CME activity spanning 2025-12-17 and 2025-12-18.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and one usable frame of STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint outflowing CME to the N observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2, with the start time representing best first visibility as the CME appears to develop within the LASCO C2 field-of-view rather than appear from behind the occulting disk. No direct source is observed for this CME, but could be far-sided outflow based on previous far-sided NE-directed CME activity spanning 2025-12-17 and 2025-12-18.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and one usable frame of STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: This CME is faintly visible to the E/SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and dissipates within the C2 field of view. The source may be some movement of magnetic field lines seen in the SE next to a coronal hole in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2025-12-18T17:45Z. It is hard to say without triangulation of more coronagraphs to confirm the potential source though.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using plane-of-sky method in SWPC_CAT. The CME dissipates within the C2 field of view and is not seen in any other coronagraph.

cmes.note: This CME is faintly visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2. It is not clearly seen in other coronagraphs due to its faintness. The CME dissipates within the C2 field of view before reaching the C3 field of view. The potential source is moving field lines and minor brightening visible to the SE of a coronal hole in the SE in GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2025-12-18T18:57Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using plane-of-sky method in SWPC_CAT. The CME dissipates within the C2 field of view and is not seen in any other coronagraph.

cmes.note: Outflow, jet-like CME to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. This CME is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The CME is hard to distinguish in C2 frames, but becomes more clear and defined in C3 frames. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky parameters using SWPC_CAT and the best fit with SOHO LASCO C3 frames.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption observed beyond the western limb starting around 2025-12-19T00:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is observed over the western limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NNE part way into the FOV of SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-12-19T20:00Z. This front is also seen to the NNE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. It is very faint and is only seen in running difference imagery. There is no definitive source candidate on the Earth-facing disk, so the source could be far-sided. This feature could also be related to a prominence over the NE limb seen starting to rise in SDO AIA 304 as early as 2025-12-19T17:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of definitive source candidate and lack of available coronagraph triangulation.

cmes.note: CME observed to the E in STEREO A COR2, GOES CCOR-1, and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source is a M1.0 class flare from AR 14315 (N19E57) which peaked at 2025-12-20T07:53Z observed in SDO AIA 131, also observed as field line movement and dimming in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint, fast CME observed to the NE only in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, may be too faint for GOES CCOR-1 and not observed in STEREO A COR2 likely due to longitude away from the spacecraft. The source is likely filament ejecta observed in SDO AIA 304 on/just beyond the E limb starting around 2025-12-20T16:21Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2 due to faintness in LASCO C3, no visibility in other coronagraphs, likely slightly far-sided source, and a half width of less than 10 degrees.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source for this CME is not clear: there are two very minor eruptions happening in the NE quadrant just before 2025-12-20T20Z - one on/behind the NE limb and another in AR 14312 (N19E40), with minor ejecta seen in SDO AIA 304 and minor dimming and brightening seen in SDO AIA 195 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Because this CME is covered by a large daily data gap in STEREO A coronagraph and its source is not clear (there are a couple of different potential sources), the CME is measured with plane-of-sky analysis using SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraph.
